header.subtitle: Exploring freedom through a non-traditional sport

text.value: On Sunday afternoon El Prado, the smooth, stone promenade that divides Old and Central Havana, is full of life. Painters line the walkway, dipping brushes into the bright yellows and blues that make their art Cuban in the eyes of tourists. Other craftsmen have set up tables and chairs in the middle of the promenade, where they carve small wooden statues or thread colorful beads into bracelets. Ahead, a little closer to the seaside, small children play leapfrog and chase each other on bikes and scooters. Parents and strangers crowd around as a 10-year-old boy lifts and twirls his dance partner, a small girl wearing flat ballet shoes and her hair in a tight bun. She holds her form like someone who’s been dancing for longer than she’s been alive. The air carries the timba beat –trombones, conga drums and the clap, clap… clap of the clave – along with the smell of the Atlantic Ocean toward the heart of the city.

A teenager on pink roller blades maneuvers through the dance performance, stopping at a bench crowded with tattooed teens sharing a cigarette. In Cuba, tattooing is illegal in all circumstances, and, without a legal age restriction, it’s not uncommon to see older teens with tattoos they got from an makeshift parlor set up in a dilapidated Havana apartment. At their feet, skateboards scatter the ground. The sound of silicone wheels slapping the marble surface overwhelms the place as skaters land ollies and kickflips and toss their boards onto the hard floor. An 8-year-old boy skates up to a group of guys in their early 20’s, and daps them up like old friends. Age doesn’t seem to be discriminating factor here, and neither does style. Skaters in black share the street with Hawaiian shirts and gym shorts. Here, punk and rock and rasta are all familia. They’ve come to El Prado for a competition, many with twisted ankles or broken boards, happy just to be there witnessing the action.

The noise gradually fades and the street clears but for two lone skaters: a tall one with dyed blonde curls peaking out from under a black snapback, and a 12-year-old rolling behind him. All the commotion has stopped, and an ominous quiet sets in. Skaters sit along the walls conversing in hushed voices as two men wearing stiff, gray uniforms and old-fashioned barrettes stroll through El Prado. They walk with purpose, examining the throng of skaters with suspicion, pausing only to speak to the two rebels who continue skating. Finally, they walk away, the two young skaters trailing leisurely behind in a cooperative, but unenthusiastic manner. Just like that, everything goes back to normal. The skaters pile back onto the street, the loud bangs and chatter and laughter filling the air once more. None of the skaters mention the disappearance of their friends or seem concerned about their welfare. And, when two more are taken away 30 minutes later, the reaction is equally indifferent.

“When you see police, you sit,” said Junnior Gilberto Terré, 20, who’s perched on a concrete bench rolling a skateboard back and forth with his leg, which is bandaged at the knee. Junnior has come to El Prado to visit friends, chain smoke cigarettes and maybe try out a few tricks now that his knee is healing. It’s been more than a year since he injured it landing a faulty jump and he’s eager to get back in the air.

Junnior’s face becomes pensive, his reddish brows scrunch together and his pale cheeks go hollow as he takes a long drag from his cigarette and thinks about his future. He’s been skating since he was 16 years old. Four years of heelflips and boardslides and elbow scrapes and strained muscles. Four years of falling and getting back up and being arrested and paying fines. Like most skaters his age, he dreams of sponsors, the X Games and prize money. But for skaters in his country, it’s likely to remain just that: a dream. In Cuba, you can make a living as a professional boxer, baseball player or ballerina, but for a non-traditionally Cuban sport like skating, there’s no money to be made. Skaters here are going against the grain. The act of skating itself is an expression of freedom. It demonstrates this generation’s ability to break free of the strict traditions found in Cuba. However, despite everything they have overcome in order to skate, they have a long way to go before their dreams of going pro and having the support of Cuban society can become a reality.

Seventeen-year-old Cristian Alonzo Stewart traded a pullover, a backpack and a pair of shoes for his first skateboard. And it wasn’t a good one. Cuban skaters can’t simply ride to the skate shop and buy a new pair of Vans when theirs begin to fall apart, or replace the deck they broke grinding on a rail. In Cuba, there are no skate shops. Equipment is usually donated by organizations from other countries and then bartered for and passed around among skaters.

“It’s not like other countries where you can buy shoes or skateboards very easily,” Cristian said. “You need to work hard. Or if you’re lucky and your parents have money you can buy different shoes all the time, but many people here don’t have that possibility.”

But even if a skater can get hold of the equipment, learning to skate is another challenge. With just ONE [?] skate park in the entire country, there’s no place to cultivate skate talent. In the United States, if skaters want to learn to slide down a stair railing, they start at the skate park, where they learn to jump onto lower rails and gradually improve until they’re ready for the big one. But here, they go straight for the big one and hope they don’t break a bone or, more importantly, a board.  Additionally, there are no professional skaters in the country or other experts to teach skaters advanced moves. They mostly learn from each other, looking up to the best of their peers, like Fabian Lopez and Alvaro Lores who are sponsored by Toda Fuerza, an organization designed specifically to support Havana-based skateboarders.

El Prado’s flat, polished surface makes it one of the best places to skate in all of Havana. It’s also one of the countless places in this city where skateboarding is prohibited. “The police will ban us one day, and then they will be fine with us the next day,” Cristian said. “They don’t get much respect from skateboarders.” Most of the skaters here have been reprimanded, fined and taken to jail numerous times. But, to them, the worst punishment is a broken board. When the police confiscate a skateboard and return it in two pieces, the skater will have to wait months before a foreigner comes to donate another deck or until he or she has enough saved up to barter for a new board.
